intro: Leptomischus erianthus, commonly known as the woolly mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. It has small, scale-like leaves that are covered in a dense layer of white, woolly hairs, which give it its common name. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers that are typically clustered together, followed by small, fleshy berries that are an important food source for birds. Its parasitic nature allows it to absorb water and nutrients from its host, while still carrying out some photosynthesis. Due to its unique appearance and ecological role, it is often found in shaded, humid environments.
